title: 107_hr2830
content: The "Voting Restoration Act" is the short title of this Act, which aims to restore voting rights. The Voting Restoration Act aims to restore voting rights by addressing disparities in voting eligibility standards for ex-felons across different states. Congress asserts its supervisory power over federal elections to ensure voting rights are not denied based on race, sex, color, or previous servitude. Approximately 2 percent of the adult population, or 3,900,000 Americans, are currently ineligible to vote due to felony convictions. The process to regain voting rights varies by state, with some requiring a pardon or order from the Governor, while federal offenders must obtain a Presidential pardon. The number of incarcerated individuals has increased significantly in recent years, partly due to strict drug policies. The prison population has grown due to harsh drug policies, with 1 in 4 inmates in 1998 incarcerated for drug offenses. Drug offenders made up 58% of Federal prison inmates in 1998, with a significant number being nonviolent. Racially disparate sentencing laws have led to African-Americans being disproportionately convicted for drug charges. Minorities are disproportionately impacted by these laws. Minorities, especially African-American men, are disproportionately affected by laws that strip felons of their voting rights. Congress should address these disparities to ensure all Americans have the right to vote in Federal elections. The purpose of the Act is to restore voting eligibility to individuals who have completed their criminal sentences and promote their participation in civic life. The Act aims to protect the right to vote and register to vote in federal elections. The Act protects the voting rights of individuals with felony convictions, allowing restrictions only during custody or supervision. Violations can be reported to state election officials for corrective action within 90 days. The Act allows aggrieved persons to bring a civil action for declaratory or injunctive relief within specific time frames after receiving a notice of violation. If the violation occurs within 30 days of a Federal election, notice to the chief election official is not required to bring a civil action. Compensatory damages may be requested in a civil action for violations of the Act within 3 days of a Federal election. The Attorney General can also take legal action for declaratory or injunctive relief to address violations of the Act. Grant program to assist states in protecting rights of ex-felons to vote and register in federal elections. Establishment of a program to award grants to eligible States for assisting individuals convicted of felonies to vote and register in Federal elections. Establishment of a program to award grants to eligible States for assisting individuals convicted of felonies to vote and register in Federal elections. States must meet eligibility requirements and submit an application to the Attorney General to receive a grant amount based on the total appropriation for the year. The program awards grants to states based on the percentage of convicted felons in the state compared to all eligible states. States must provide information on voting rights to felons. The program awards grants to states based on the percentage of convicted felons in the state compared to all eligible states. States must establish and maintain an index of felons under custody or supervision, including information on their voting eligibility. The State must inform individuals about their right to register and vote, including during plea bargaining and after a felony conviction. They must also provide information on voting eligibility upon release from custody or completion of supervision. The State must notify individuals of their right to register and vote, including through various means like media, Internet, and cooperative agreements. States receiving grants must report their activities to the Attorney General within 30 days after the year ends. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by informing them of their right to vote. States receiving grants are encouraged to reduce the number of felonies leading to disenfranchisement. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by establishing an index of eligible voters and implementing activities to boost registration rates by at least 50% over a 5-year period. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by establishing an index of eligible voters and implementing activities to boost registration rates. States receiving grants under the program must carry out activities to increase voting rates among convicted felons, seeking assistance from public and private entities. Each State receiving a grant under the program must report to the Attorney General within 30 days after the year ends, detailing activities and the number of convicted felons registered to vote and who voted in the latest elections. The Attorney General will provide technical assistance to States for program implementation and submit an annual report to relevant committees. The Attorney General will submit a report to the Judiciary Committees of the House and Senate on program activities and information provided by participating States. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the first 5 fiscal years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. RESPONSIBILITIES OF DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE REGARDING INDIVIDUALS CONVICTED OF FEDERAL FELONIES. The Attorney General will maintain an index of individuals convicted of felonies by the Federal Government and inform them of their right to register and vote. The Attorney General will submit an annual report to Congress detailing the activities related to informing individuals convicted of felonies of their right to register and vote. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "chief election official," "election," "Federal office," and "State." SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect eligibility to vote in non-Federal elections and does not supersede the Voting Rights Act or the National Voter Registration Act.
